context: The characteristics of DMS biodegradation in association with the increase of biomass concentration are discussed. RSM was applied to optimize the conditions for batch growth. The kinetic analysis for substrate degradation and bacterial growth was accomplished by fitting a Haldane–Andrew model and a pseudo first-order model. Chemicals and cultivation medium The composition of the mineral salt medium (MSM) used in the batch experiment was 4.5g Na2HPO4·12H2O, 2.5g KH2PO4, 1.0g NH4HCO3, 0.2g MgCl2·7H2O, 0.03g CaCl2·2H2O, and 0.01g FeCl2·4H2O in 1L deionized water and 1mL of trace element stock solution. The trace element stock solution contained 1.0gL−1 FeCl2·7H2O, 0.02gL−1 CuCl2·5H2O, 0.014gL−1 H3BO3, 0.10gL−1 MnCl2·4H2O, 0.10gL−1 ZnCl2 7H2O, 0.02gL−1 Na2MoO4·2H2O, and 0.02gL−1 CoCl2·6H2O. The initial inoculation volume for microbial cultures was 1mL, and the bacterial solution was adjusted to an optical density (OD) of 1.0 at 600nm. DMS (>99%) was obtained from Sigma–Aldrich (Mainland, China).Isolation and identification of the strain The bacterial strain used in this study was isolated from the activated sludge of a pharmaceutical plant (Taizhou, China) and cultured in 250mL shake flasks that contained 50mL liquid medium at 30°C and were shaken at 180rpm.
